editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msItem.note: Fols. i, ii-iv blank. On f. iv is written a philosophical problem.

physDesc.p: Four originally separate volumes, the last two incomplete, probably all together early.

supportDesc.extent:
173 leaves (iv + 169) 205 145
140–60 106
The edges heavily retrimmed with loss of marginalia and stained red.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled with crayon, written in c. 25–35 lines.

handDesc.handNote: Several English cursive hands, not very uniform, writing a mixture of anglicana and secretary.

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue initials flourished in red; red titles, marginal guides, paraphs, highlighting and underlining of lemmata.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii; sewn on four bands, formerly chained from the usual position.

history.provenance: At the head of f. 1 ‘Ex emptione sociorum huius domus anno Domini M. 452’.

Inside the front board is a sheet of paper with a table of contents, ‘E. 4. 15’, and ‘P. 4. 11. Art:’, s. xvii, the last two items canc. and repeated in the same hand on f. ivv, the last replaced by ‘C. 2. 11 (CCLX)’, in red ink; the College bookplate. ‘11’ is inked on the foredge.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Coxe, pp. 102–3; Powicke, no. 925; Codices Boethiani, no. 224; Dondaine & Shooner, no. 2129; DSO (Gál), 2. 13–14, 258.

msItem.author: ALBERT OF SAXONY
msItem.title: De Modo Significandi
msItem.incipit: Quoniam scire et intelligere contingit in omni scientia
msItem.explicit: (f. 24v) et hec de modis significandi essentialibus et accidentalibus scilicet partium orationis prout pertinent ad etymologiam. Hec dicta sufficiunt.
msItem.incipit: Habito de modis significandi partium orationis sub ratione qua sunt principium formale partium orationis siue sermonis
msItem.explicit: sed quanta per nuper. Et hec dicta de passionibus sufficiunt sermonum.
msItem.finalRubric: Deo gracias. Scriptor premissi tractatus nomine Manby.

msItem.title: De Modis Significandi
msItem.incipit: Vt habeatur cognicio regiminis in grammatica secundum modos significandi proporcionales
(35v) Nunc unumquodque arbitramur scire cum causas suas cognoscimus
(48v) Reuerendi domini quia in contextu presentis sermonis singule partes orationis secundum speciem propter coniunctionem
msItem.explicit: omnis efficacia arguendi que omnia sub specie uere supportationis benigne.

msItem.author: FRANCISCUS DE MAYRONIS
msItem.title: De Signis Naturae
msItem.incipit: Primum signum nature quiditatum ut quiditas entis siue entitas
msItem.note: Unpr. Roth, Franz von Mayronis, p. 213 n. 44, refers to art. 2 and understandably doubted that it was written by Meyronnes. However, the incipit of art. 3 shows it to be the genuine work, of which Roth, pp. 212–13, cites six other copies.

handDesc.handNote: Art. 1 is signed by ‘Manby’ , who should be John Manbe, monk of Durham (BRUO 1212–13; Thomson, Lincoln, p. 200 and pl. 34), occ. 1471–2, 1494, known as an annotator of other books; however, in those cases (perhaps when he was older) he wrote a version of humanistica.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Interpretatione, bk. 1
msItem.incipit: Primum quidem oportet constituere. Notandum circa subiectum huius libri quod Boecius ponit idem esse interpretacionem
msItem.explicit: ad ipsum ut est in propositione ubi distribuitur ut omnis homo currit &c.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit opus Dunce super primum librum Peryarmenias.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Interpretatione, bks. 1–2.
msItem.incipit: Queritur circa secundum librum primo an uerbum infinitum maneat infinitum in oratione
msItem.explicit: ibidem denotantur inesse ideo est propositio plures.
msItem.finalRubric: Deo gracias et sic finitur secundus liber. Explicit primum opus Dunce super primum librum Perihermenias. Sequitur secundum opus eiusdem doctoris super primum librum.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Interpretatione, bks. 1–2 (opus alterum)
msItem.incipit: Sicut dicit philosophus iii. de anima triplex est operatio intellectus
msItem.explicit: in propositione ideo non est de presenti. Finis.

msItem.author: JOHN DUNS SCOTUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, Sophistici Elenchi
msItem.incipit: De sophisticis autem elenchis &c. Queritur utrum logica procedat ex communibus quod non
msItem.explicit: non sequitur priuatio respectus ad aliud.
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt questiones Duns super librum Elencorum. Chapeleyn.
msItem.note: DSO (Gál), 2. 271–527, using four copies including this one (O); Lohr, p. 192.

msItem.author: THOMAS AQUINAS
msItem.title: De Occultis Operationibus Naturae
msItem.incipit: Quoniam in quibusdam naturalibus corporibus quedam acciones naturales apparent
msItem.explicit: de accionibus occultis ad presens dicta sufficiant.

msItem.author: BOETHIUS
msItem.title: De Hebdomadibus
msItem.incipit: Postulas utrum ex ebdomadibus naturis eius questionis obscuritatem
msItem.explicit: alia quidam iusta at alia uero aliud omnia igitur bona &c.
msItem.note: CPL 892; ed. and transl. H. F. Steward and E. K. Rand (London, 1918/1973), pp. 38–50.

handDesc.handNote: Art. 7 was written by Chapeleyn, perhaps Peter Chapeleyn (BRUO 388), notary public, who witnessed documents of University College in 1445.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 152 Chapeleyn’s colophon, in large capitals, is decorated with skilful pen-and-ink sprays of flowers and foliage.

msItem.title: De Ente et Essentia
msItem.incipit: Qui errat circa principia multo magis circa principita. Vltima nostra perfectio consistit in intelligibili operatione
msItem.explicit: (ends impf.) quia sunt materialia et materia
